page.title: 06THE THURSO SALMON
page.content: Fishing for salmon has taken place on{Thurso River}for hundreds of years. The biggest known single haul of fish was in the 1750s when about 2,000 fish were taken. Today the catch for the season is 3,000 salmon. The record catch was taken in Cruives Pool, now known as the Salmon Pool, which is still a popular fishing spot today. The salmon fishermen today use a coble - the special kind of salmon boat - with an electric engine but in the past the boat would have been rowed. This system of operation using a coble involves four men. Two in the boat and two on the shore. Up to 15 years ago six men worked as a team. Four in the coble and two working the nets from dry land. There is a ready market for the catch in{Thurso}and further afield.
